text: I was looking at the Keychron K6 (<https://www.keychron.com/products/keychron-k6-wireless-mechanical-keyboard>) looks sooooo good, but shipping to canada adds another $24 on top which is fairly steep

attachments.title: Keychron K6 Wireless Mechanical Keyboard
attachments.text: Keychron K6 Compact Wireless Mechanical Keyboard. 65% Layout. Wireless or Wired. Users can hot swap every switch in seconds with the hot-swappable version. Compatible with Mac, Windows, iOS, Android, Linux. Optical or Gateron Switches. Connect up to 3 devices. 15+ RGB Backlight

elements.text: I was looking at the Keychron K6 (
) looks sooooo good, but shipping to canada adds another $24 on top which is fairly steep
I don’t really understand the popularity of mechanical keyboards. Doesn’t it add more stress to wrists?
Why would it do that?

text: Because you have to hit it harder and deeper?

elements.text: Because you have to hit it harder and deeper?

text: You don't necessarily have to hit harder or deeper. The point of a mechanical keyboard is that you don't need to bottom out a key to activate it

elements.text: You don't necessarily have to hit harder or deeper. The point of a mechanical keyboard is that you don't need to bottom out a key to activate it

text: Eg. the key can keep moving past the activation point, so there's less impact from each keystroke if you're not bottoming out

elements.text: Eg. the key can keep moving past the activation point, so there's less impact from each keystroke if you're not bottoming out

text: Interesting, I don’t know about that feature. Maybe the best way is to just try it myself :slightly_smiling_face:

text: Plus you get the nice click clack! (Other nearby may not find this as appealing)

text: I haven't tried one either, and the price always stopped me from taking the plunge, but my supervisor offered to buy me a fancy ergonomic one for my RSI, so I'm excited for that to arrive!

text: They’re very nice, if you’re using them in a shared environment I would look for ones which have quieter keys.

elements.text: They’re very nice, if you’re using them in a shared environment I would look for ones which have quieter keys.

text: The keyboard I'm getting has swappable switches so I'm not too worried. Starting with Cherry MX Brown which are apparently pretty quiet at least for mechanical keyboards

text: I'd never be able to justify buying such a thing myself, but my supervisor takes ergonomics very seriously and has a ton of left over grant money this year due to no conferences, so yay.
